SubTopics: In literary texts, analyze how elements of plot are related, affect one another, and contribute to meaning. In informational texts, analyze how individuals, events, and ideas are introduced, relate to each other, and are developed.
Content: What do the details in paragraphs 5 through 9 mainly reveal about Kareem?

A.Choice: He wishes to visit more museums.

B.Choice: He prefers listening to jazz music.

C.Choice: He enjoys playing competitive games.

D.Choice: He desires to learn more about his heritage.

SubTopics: Use established criteria in order to evaluate the quality of texts. Make connections to other texts, ideas, cultural perspectives, eras, and personal experiences.
Content: Which quotation best represents the idea that the opinion of classmates can have a major effect on teenagers?

A.Choice: “Size implies maturity. Yes, I was the size of an adult (actually, bigger than most!), but I was still just a kid.” (paragraph 1)

B.Choice: “As a card-carrying Good Boy, I wanted to meet adults' expectations and get their praise, but as a Regular Kid, I wanted to be like my peers and get their friendship...” (paragraph 1)

C.Choice: “Weekends, I hung out with my only close friend left in the projects, Norbert.” (paragraph 5)

D.Choice: “And back and forth we'd go, trying to one-up the other in a cultural heritage version of rock, paper, scissors.” (paragraph 9)

SubTopics: In literary texts, analyze how an author develops and contrasts the point of view and the perspectives of different characters or narrators. In informational texts, analyze how the author distinguishes his or her position from that of others.
Content: Which statement best describes the importance of Norbert in Kareem's life?

A.Choice: “We would shut ourselves in my room to play chess and talk about our plans for the future.” (paragraph 5)

B.Choice: “... both of us had started to take an interest in finding out more about our ethnic origins.” (paragraph 6)

C.Choice: “And back and forth we'd go, trying to one-up the other in a cultural heritage version of rock, paper, scissors.” (paragraph 9)

D.Choice: “... I had a friend in whom I could confide any thought or feeling, knowing he would never make fun of me.” (paragraph 9)

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative and connotative meanings. Analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning, tone, and mood, including words with multiple meanings.
Content: In paragraph 10, what does Kareem mean when he says, “I didn't have an aggressive nature”?

A.Choice: He believes he needs to change the way he plays basketball.

B.Choice: He understands he may not be a strong player because of his age.

C.Choice: He discovers the other players know more ways to score in basketball.

D.Choice: He realizes he needs to practice more if he wants to improve as a player.

SubTopics: In literary texts, analyze how elements of plot are related, affect one another, and contribute to meaning. In informational texts, analyze how individuals, events, and ideas are introduced, relate to each other, and are developed.
Content: What does paragraph 14 show about the relationship between Kareem and Coach Donahue?

A.Choice: Kareem and Coach Donahue understand the importance of studying.

B.Choice: Kareem is beginning to understand and appreciate Coach Donahue's personality.

C.Choice: Kareem expected Coach Donahue's decision to have him play varsity.

D.Choice: Kareem is worried that Coach Donahue is disappointed by his performance as a player.

SubTopics: Determine a theme or central idea of a text and analyze its development over the course of the text; summarize a text.
Content: Which quotation best expresses a central idea in the article?

A.Choice: “The scary thing about being so tall when you're so young is that people automatically treat you as if you're older.” (paragraph 1)

B.Choice: “My refuge from the explosive turmoil outside, and the implosive turmoil I had started to feel inside, was basketball.” (paragraph 4)

C.Choice: “We even took the subway to the Metropolitan Museum of Art to find out more about Filipino and African cultures.” (paragraph 9)

D.Choice: “I hurried away on a mission to tell anyone who would listen that I would be playing varsity that afternoon.” (paragraph 15)

SubTopics: In literary texts, analyze how elements of plot are related, affect one another, and contribute to meaning. In informational texts, analyze how individuals, events, and ideas are introduced, relate to each other, and are developed.
Content: How is Kareem and Norbert's friendship developed in the article?

A.Choice: The authors describe the various interests that Kareem and Norbert have.

B.Choice: The authors use cause and effect to describe how Kareem and Norbert became friends.

C.Choice: The authors present a problem Kareem and Norbert encounter and describe how they solve it.

D.Choice: The authors compare and contrast the friendship of Kareem and Norbert to the friendships of other students.

SubTopics: In literary texts, analyze how an author develops and contrasts the point of view and the perspectives of different characters or narrators. In informational texts, analyze how the author distinguishes his or her position from that of others.
Content: How do lines 1 through 8 develop the speaker's point of view?

A.Choice: by revealing why the speaker dislikes being around people

B.Choice: by explaining why the speaker moved away from the sea

C.Choice: by showing how the speaker knows the reason for feeling discontented

D.Choice: by suggesting the speaker is happiest when moving from place to place

SubTopics: In literary texts, analyze how structure, including genrespecific features, contributes to the development of themes and central ideas. In informational texts, analyze the structure an author uses to organize a text, including how the sections contribute to the whole and to the development of themes and central ideas.
Content: How do lines 1 through 16 (the first two stanzas) contribute to the structure of the poem?

A.Choice: They introduce the conflict the speaker feels about her opportunities in different places.

B.Choice: They contrast the speaker's experiences and feelings about living in different places.

C.Choice: They compare phases in the speaker's life when she wanted to be in a different place.

D.Choice: They show the causes and effects of the speaker deciding to live in a different place.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative and connotative meanings. Analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning, tone, and mood, including words with multiple meanings.
Content: The repetition of the phrase “once again” in lines 19, 23, 25, and 27 affects the meaning of the poem by

A.Choice: indicating the main places the speaker wishes to revisit

B.Choice: emphasizing how strongly the speaker wishes to return to the sea

C.Choice: illustrating some of the speaker's most cherished memories

D.Choice: revealing the speaker's concern about some features of the sea

SubTopics: Determine a theme or central idea of a text and analyze its development over the course of the text; summarize a text.
Content: Which lines best support a theme of the poem?

A.Choice:
:box:“Searching my heart for its true sorrow,
	This is the thing I find to be:
That I am weary of words and people,
	Sick of the city, wanting the sea;” (lines 1–4)

B.Choice:
:box:“If I could hear the green piles groaning
	Under the windy, wooden piers,
See once again the bobbing barrels,
	And the black sticks that fence the weirs;” (lines 17–20)

C.Choice:
:box:“If I could see the weedy mussels
	Crusting the wrecked and rotting hulls,
Hear once again the hungry crying
	Overhead, of the wheeling gulls.” (lines 21–24)

D.Choice:
:box:“Feel once again the shanty straining
	Under the turning of the tide,
Fear once again the rising freshet,
	Dread the bell in the fog outside,” (lines 25–28)

SubTopics: In literary texts, analyze how elements of plot are related, affect one another, and contribute to meaning. In informational texts, analyze how individuals, events, and ideas are introduced, relate to each other, and are developed.
Content: Which phrase best states the speaker's problem in the poem?

A.Choice: “Wanting the loud sound and the soft sound” (line 7)

B.Choice: “Crusting the wrecked and rotting hulls,” (line 22)

C.Choice: “Fear once again the rising freshet,” (line 27)

D.Choice: “I am too long away from the water;” (line 35)

SubTopics: In literary texts, analyze how elements of plot are related, affect one another, and contribute to meaning. In informational texts, analyze how individuals, events, and ideas are introduced, relate to each other, and are developed.
Content: In lines 1 through 8 of “Exiled,” why does the speaker describe the setting? Use two details from the poem to support your response.

SubTopics: Trace and evaluate the development of an argument and specific claims in a text, assessing whether the reasoning is valid and the evidence is relevant and sufficient and recognizing when irrelevant evidence is introduced.
Content: How does the speaker support her claim about life by the sea? Use two details from the poem to support your response.

SubTopics: Determine a theme or central idea of a text and analyze its development over the course of the text; summarize a text.
Content: How does paragraph 4 develop a theme in the story?

A.Choice: by identifying the mother's opinion about Haydn

B.Choice: by describing the crates where the mother keeps her music

C.Choice: by showing the value of music in the mother's life

D.Choice: by explaining the importance of the concert for the mother

SubTopics: In literary texts, analyze how elements of plot are related, affect one another, and contribute to meaning. In informational texts, analyze how individuals, events, and ideas are introduced, relate to each other, and are developed.
Content: Which quotation shows a change in the direction of the story?

A.Choice: “... she landed in Takoma Park, at Ahimsa House.” (paragraph 2)

B.Choice: “But he loved hearing stories about the people who lived there.” (paragraph 3)

C.Choice: “When Josh was five, he discovered the cello.” (paragraph 4)

D.Choice: “The next day, Mom signed him up for cello lessons...” (paragraph 5)

SubTopics: In literary texts, analyze how elements of plot are related, affect one another, and contribute to meaning. In informational texts, analyze how individuals, events, and ideas are introduced, relate to each other, and are developed.
Content: In paragraph 6, how does the narrator's question to Josh affect the resolution of the story?

A.Choice: by giving Josh an opportunity to express his feelings

B.Choice: by letting the narrator share a memory with her brother

C.Choice: by revealing how Josh has grown in his ability to play the cello

D.Choice: by allowing the narrator to make dinner while her brother is occupied

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative and connotative meanings. Analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning, tone, and mood, including words with multiple meanings.
Content: In paragraph 8, the word “wilted” most likely means that Josh is

A.Choice: confused

B.Choice: frustrated

C.Choice: sad

D.Choice: tired

SubTopics: Use established criteria in order to evaluate the quality of texts. Make connections to other texts, ideas, cultural perspectives, eras, and personal experiences.
Content: People often use food as a way to create a sense of community. Which phrase from the story best supports this idea?

A.Choice: “Everyone took turns cooking” (paragraph 1)

B.Choice: “Cottage Cheese Contraption, invented by an old woman” (paragraph 2)

C.Choice: “when Mom served chai lattes at the Sunflower Café” (paragraph 3)

D.Choice: “fried it all into a delicious hot mush, while Josh 'talked' to me” (paragraph 9)

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative and connotative meanings. Analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning, tone, and mood, including words with multiple meanings.
Content: In paragraph 9, why is the word “talked” in quotation marks?

A.Choice: Josh does not wish to have a discussion with the narrator.

B.Choice: Josh communicates with the narrator by using the cello as his voice.

C.Choice: Josh only pretends to communicate with the narrator.

D.Choice: Josh does not want the narrator to share his feelings with their mother.

SubTopics: In literary texts, analyze how an author develops and contrasts the point of view and the perspectives of different characters or narrators. In informational texts, analyze how the author distinguishes his or her position from that of others.
Content: How does the author best develop the narrator's point of view in the story?

A.Choice: by sharing the narrator's memories

B.Choice: by describing the narrator's opinions

C.Choice: through the narrator's reactions to events

D.Choice: through the narrator's dialogue

SubTopics: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.
Content: Which word best defines the phrase “family myth” in paragraph 1?

A.Choice: fantasy

B.Choice: background

C.Choice: promise

D.Choice: knowledge

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative and connotative meanings. Analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning, tone, and mood, including words with multiple meanings.
Content: What does the word “footnote” mean as it is used in paragraph 2?

A.Choice: a reference to an idea

B.Choice: a small but important role

C.Choice: an accomplishment of a goal

D.Choice: an explanation or definition of an event

SubTopics: In literary texts, analyze how structure, including genrespecific features, contributes to the development of themes and central ideas. In informational texts, analyze the structure an author uses to organize a text, including how the sections contribute to the whole and to the development of themes and central ideas.
Content: How does paragraph 3 contribute to the organization of the article?

A.Choice: It introduces the distrust that existed in Liz Bedell's family.

B.Choice: It foreshadows that Liz Bedell and her family will be surprised by the truth.

C.Choice: It establishes the position Liz Bedell's grandfather had in the family.

D.Choice: It shows how little Liz Bedell knew about her past.

SubTopics: Determine a theme or central idea of a text and analyze its development over the course of the text; summarize a text.
Content: How does paragraph 10 contribute to the development of a central idea in the article?

A.Choice: by demonstrating Liz Bedell's experience in different states

B.Choice: by identifying important people that Liz Bedell knows

C.Choice: by revealing the effect of Liz Bedell's grandfather's influence on her

D.Choice: by showing how Liz Bedell chose to honor her great-great aunt's legacy

SubTopics: Trace and evaluate the development of an argument and specific claims in a text, assessing whether the reasoning is valid and the evidence is relevant and sufficient and recognizing when irrelevant evidence is introduced.
Content: In paragraph 12, Grace Bedell supports her argument that Lincoln should grow a beard. Which statement does not support the argument?

A.Choice: “I have got 4 brother's and part of them will vote for you any way...”

B.Choice: “... if you will let your whiskers grow I will try and get the rest of them to vote for you...”

C.Choice: “... you would look a great deal better for your face is so thin...”

D.Choice: “All the ladies like whiskers and they would tease their husband's to vote for you...”

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative and connotative meanings. Analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning, tone, and mood, including words with multiple meanings.
Content: In paragraph 15, what does the word “flustered” suggest?

A.Choice: Grace Bedell became shy around the large crowd.

B.Choice: Meeting Abraham Lincoln was worrisome for Grace Bedell.

C.Choice: Grace Bedell lost interest in the candidate by the time of the meeting.

D.Choice: Receiving a kiss from Abraham Lincoln made Grace Bedell nervous.

SubTopics: In literary texts, analyze how an author develops and contrasts the point of view and the perspectives of different characters or narrators. In informational texts, analyze how the author distinguishes his or her position from that of others.
Content: Which quotation best reveals the author's purpose for writing the article?

A.Choice: “... she dismissed as 'family myth' a story her grandfather often told about his Aunt Grace Bedell.” (paragraph 1)

B.Choice: “Her grandfather encouraged her to pursue a lifelong interest in politics.” (paragraph 8)

C.Choice: “As to the whiskers, having never worn any, do you not think people would call it a piece of silly affectation... ?” (paragraph 14)

D.Choice: “He explained that this Lincoln exhibition was the first time, to his knowledge, that the two letters had been displayed together.” (paragraph 16)

SubTopics: In literary texts, analyze how an author develops and contrasts the point of view and the perspectives of different characters or narrators. In informational texts, analyze how the author distinguishes his or her position from that of others.
Content: In “[Excerpt from] Art for the Sea,” how does the author convey her opinion about pollution in the oceans? Use two details from the article to support your response.

SubTopics: Determine a theme or central idea of a text and analyze its development over the course of the text; summarize a text.
Content: In “[Excerpt from] The Best Way to Deal with Ocean Trash,” how do details in the section “The Garbage Patches” help develop a central idea of the article? Use two details from the article to support your response.

SubTopics: In literary texts, analyze how elements of plot are related, affect one another, and contribute to meaning. In informational texts, analyze how individuals, events, and ideas are introduced, relate to each other, and are developed.
Content: In “[Excerpt from] The Best Way to Deal with Ocean Trash,” why does the author include ideas from the scientists Haymet and Wilcox in the section “Addressing the Problem”? Use two details from the article to support your response.

SubTopics: Trace and evaluate the development of an argument and specific claims in a text, assessing whether the reasoning is valid and the evidence is relevant and sufficient and recognizing when irrelevant evidence is introduced.
Content: In “[Excerpt from] Art for the Sea” and “[Excerpt from] The Best Way to Deal with Ocean Trash,” both authors present claims about plastic trash. What is each author's claim? How does each author support this claim? Which author's argument is more convincing? Use details from both articles to support your response.

:box:In your response, be sure to

• identify the claim that each author makes
• explain how each author supports this claim
• explain which author's argument is more convincing use details from both articles to support your response
